Copper nanoparticles control of carbon supported copper catalysts for dimethyl carbonate synthesis: A short review Peiyu Zhao Formal analysis Writing – review & editing Supervision a ⁎ Junfen Yan Formal analysis Writing – original draft b Bingquan Shan Writing – original draft Formal analysis a Yu Zhang Writing – original draft a Zhiyuan Zhao Writing – original draft a Li Liu Writing – original draft a Zhi Su Writing – original draft c Wei Cheng Writing – review & editing Supervision a ⁎ Xianmang Xu Writing – review & editing a a Heze Branch, Qilu University of Technology (Shandong Academy of Sciences), Biological Engineering Technology Innovation Center of Shandong Province, Heze, 274000, PR China Heze Branch Qilu University of Technology (Shandong Academy of Sciences) Biological Engineering Technology Innovation Center of Shandong Province Heze 274000 PR China aHeze Branch, Qilu University of Technology (Shandong Academy of Sciences), Biological Engineering Technology Innovation Center of Shandong Province, Heze, 274000, PR China b Shandong Advanced Chemical Research Institute, Heze, 274000, PR China Shandong Advanced Chemical Research Institute Heze 274000 PR China bShandong Advanced Chemical Research Institute, Heze, 274000, PR China c Heze Ecological Environment Monitoring Center of Shandong Province, Heze, 274000, PR China Heze Ecological Environment Monitoring Center of Shandong Province Heze 274000 PR China cHeze Ecological Environment Monitoring Center of Shandong Province, Heze, 274000, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. The preparation of high value-added chemicals such as dimethyl carbonate (DMC) by oxidative carbonylation of methanol with carbon materials supported copper (Cu) catalysts is an important development direction of clean and efficient utilization of coal. However, Cu nanoparticles of carbon supported copper catalysts are prone to agglomeration and oxidation in the catalytic process of oxidative carbonylation of methanol. And the development of catalysts is the key issue whether the oxidative carbonylation of methanol to DMC can be industrialized. The Cu species can be controlled by heteroatoms doping and structural confinement of carbon materials support in order to increase the catalytic activity of carbon supported copper catalysts. The recent approaches in the control of Cu nanoparticles in carbon supported copper catalysts is reviewed in this paper, the principles and characteristics of various regulation methods are introduced in detail. The problems existing in the research and the direction of improvement are then analyzed and discussed. The future development of carbon materials supported copper catalysts for the preparation of DMC was prospected. Thus, this work can provide effective guidance for the preparation of high efficiency carbon supported Cu catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Methanol Oxidative carbonylation Cu nanoparticles Carbon materials Dimethyl carbonate Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With the continuous development of coal based methanol synthesis technology and the successive commissioning of large-scale production units, the production capacity of methanol has increased significantly in recent years. The production of high value-added chemicals and fuels (such as low-carbon olefins, aromatics and organic carbonates) from methanol has become an important development direction of modern coal chemical industry [1,2]. DMC is a green chemical downstream of methanol, which is used in organic synthesis as an intermediate. Moreover, DMC has good gasoline and diesel blending performance, which is regarded as a potential oil additive [3–5]. At present, DMC synthesis methods mainly include transesterification [6], CO2 direct method [7], urea alcoholysis [8] and methanol oxidative carbonylation [9]. Among the above methods, the methanol oxidative carbonylation method uses methanol, carbon monoxide and oxygen as raw materials, with high product selectivity, and the by-product is water, which has little impact on the environment. It is an important green chemical route for the clean utilization of coal. Therefore, methanol oxidative carbonylation technology is favored by chemical environmental workers. In view of the many advantages of the catalytic methanol to DMC, the design and development of its production technology and catalyst has always been a research hotspot [10,11]. In the traditional commercial Cu based catalyst containing chlorine, the loss of Cl− is very easy to cause catalyst deactivation and equipment corrosion. The catalyst prepared with chlorine free copper as the copper source has good activity, which can fundamentally avoid the problem caused by the loss of Cl−. However, the the loss and aggregation of Cu nanoparticles during the in liquid phase reaction has become one of the major barriers to commercialization of this new catalyst. Therefore, selecting appropriate catalyst support to improve and strengthen the dispersion and stability of copper nanoparticles is a key issue in the oxidative carbonylation of methanol [12–14]. Currently, carbon materials and molecular sieve supported copper based catalysts are mainly used for oxidative carbonylation of methanol [15,16]. The excellent pore structure of carbon support can improve the dispersion of copper active metal on its surface. Moreover, when the loading amount of active metal is low, the porous carbon based support can also improve the anti-sintering ability of active metal [17]. The chemical properties of the carbon carrier surface would influence the catalytic performance of carbon catalyst. The carbon species located at the edge of the carbon material structure have unpaired electrons, which are easy to form chemical bonds with foreign heteroatoms, changing the pH of the carbon material adsorbent surface [18,19]. Therefore, the surface functionalization or heteroatom doping of carbon material can change the surface element composition of carbon materials and improve physicochemical properties of carbon materials. The above characteristics of carbon materials can further improve the interaction between carbon support and active metal, thereby improving the adsorption and catalytic properties of catalyst. In order to maintain the catalytic activity of Cu based carbon materials, scholars have proposed to improve the dispersion of Cu species by heteroatoms doping into carbon materials or using porous carbon materials to build localized copper based catalysts [20,21]. By using the pore confinement effect and doping modified carbon materials, the agglomeration and growth of active Cu species in copper based carbon materials are inhibited, thereby improving the stability of the copper based carbon materials catalyst [22,23]. In this paper, the latest research on the decentralized regulation of copper species in carbon material supported copper catalysts is reviewed in detail, the various regulation methods of Cu nanoparticles are summarized, the shortcomings of the existing research on copper based carbon material catalysts are pointed out, and the development direction of copper based carbon material catalysts is preliminarily prospected. 2 Cu nanoparticles control of carbon material catalysts 2.1 Confinement effect of carbon material for Cu nanoparticles control The improvement and strengthen the structural stability of nanoparticles under catalytic conditions has been a key scientific and technical problem in the practice of nano catalysis, especially metal nanoparticles. It has been reported that the stability of nanoparticles can be improved by ligand protection, inert carrier embedding and strong metal carrier interaction [24,25]. Most chemical reactions occur in microporous or nanoporous materials. The increase or decrease of reaction yield can be achieved through a variety of effects of such materials, including the selective absorption of reactants or products, shape selective catalysis, etc. Therefore, new materials, such as porous materials, are developed to stabilize the structure and shape of nanoparticles by using their pore geometry and electronic binding properties, while fully exposing the catalytic active center to achieve efficient catalysis [26,27]. Three copper based catalysts for methanol oxidative carbonylation, namely activated carbon (AC), ordered mesoporous carbon (OMC) and multi wall carbon nanotubes (CNTs), were developed by Zhang et al. [28] by ultrasonic assisted impregnation. As shown in Fig. 1 , Cu nanoparticles are mainly dispersed on the outer surface of AC, some Cu nanoparticles are highly dispersed in mesoporous carbon mesopores, while Cu nanoparticles are confined in the mesoporous channels of CNTs. The pore structure of carbon carrier significantly affects the dispersion of Cu nanoparticles, and pore structural of carbon support determine the average size of loaded Cu particles. Cu/CNT catalyst showed better stability during the oxidative carbonylation reaction of methanol due to the channel restriction of CNT. What distinguishes carbon nanotubes from other carbon materials is the special structure of their nanoscale cavities and walls. The curling process distorts the originally symmetrically distributed π electron cloud, resulting in the formation of an apparent potential difference inside and outside the carbon nanotubes. Such a cavity provides a unique electronic confinement environment for nano catalysts and catalytic reactions. Three kinds of copper based catalysts for methanol oxidative carbonylation supported on CNTs with different inner diameters (2-5 nm, 5-10 nm and 20-50 nm) were prepared by Zhao et al. [29]. The results show that the catalytic activity and stability of Cu nanoparticles is closely related to the inner diameter of CNTs. CNT with small inner diameter are beneficial for Cu species to enter CNTs cavity and form highly dispersed Cu particles. As shown in Fig. 2 , among all the catalysts, the dispersion and the percentage of active Cu in Cu/CNT (2-5 nm) catalysts are the largest, so this catalyst has the best initial catalytic activity for methanol. Meanwhile, Cu/CNT (5-10nm) catalyst has better stability due to the interaction between Cu and CNT (5-10nm), indicating Cu species in the Cu/CNT (5-10nm) are more stable. It can be found that the carbon nanotube confinement system directly affects the interaction between Cu nanoparticles and carbon nanotube, and then affects the catalytic reaction performance [30]. Noted that without changing the composition of the catalyst, the performance of the Cu supported catalyst can be regulated by using the confinement effect of the cavity structure of CNT. This method has great potential in the research of new catalysts development in the future. Mesoporous material has great potential in the field of catalysis due to their unique large surface area, ordered structure, uniform size and free access of macromolecules. Moreover, it has unique surface properties, excellent thermal and mechanical stability, good thermal and electrical conductivity [31,32]. Wang et al. [33] synthesized the ordered mesoporous carbon CMK-3 supported copper based catalyst by nano casting method. It was found that copper species could be evenly dispersed on the surface and mesoporous channels of CMK-3. The DMC yield of the catalyst could reach 286 mg/(g·h) after 10 hours of reaction at 450 °C. Three dimensional interconnected hierarchical mesoporous carbon supports were prepared by Pei et al. [34] using α-Cellulose as raw material and NaHCO3 as activator. The abundant micropores and mesopores in graded porous carbon enhanced the anchoring effect of copper species and promoted the dispersion of copper species in carbon materials. In addition, the three-dimensional hierarchical porous structure provides a fast and efficient channel for the migration of reactants, thereby improving the catalytic performance of the catalyst. One of the key aspects to enhance the catalytic performance of copper based catalysts for dimethyl carbonate is to develop appropriate encapsulation supports. The catalyst with excellent encapsulation supports would show better catalytic activity because it can alleviate the agglomeration and loss of copper nanoparticles. Li et al. [35] prepared hollow carbon spheres from phenolic resin and SiO2. The sphericity of carbon spheres was controlled by changing the amount of nitrogen in the synthesis process. As shown in the Fig. 3 , it is found that ideal hollow carbon spheres can be prepared when the N content is less than 5.4 wt.%. When the N content exceeds 5.4 wt.%, the encapsulation of the phenolic resin precured body is uneven and the hollow sphere structure is destroyed. After the introduction of copper species, the catalytic performance of catalysts was significantly improved because of the confinement effect of hollow carbon spheres and the electron transfer effect of available N species. When the N content was 4.0 wt.%, the copper nanoparticles was 7.4 nm, the space-time yield of DMC reached 1528 mg/(g·h). The carbon based yolk-shell nanocomposites with encapsulated copper species were synthesised directly by Hao et al. [36] from metal-oleate precursor and phenolic resin monomers through one-step co-pyrolysis. Cu oleic acid complexes can be used as organometallic precursors and as soft templates for the formation process. The cavity size of the yolk-shell nanocomposites and the amount of Cu particles can be adjusted by adjusting the reaction conditions. Cu@Carbon-YSNS showed good catalytic performance and low leaching rate during the oxidative carbonylation of methanol. Meanwhile, carbon based yolk-shell nanocomposites showed excellent thermal stability. Therefore, this work can provide new method for the design of new hollow carbon nanospheres with specific nanoparticles. Fu et al. [37] adjusted the position of copper in the hollow carbon sphere by ultrasonic assisted impregnation. Noted that compared with solid carbon spheres, hollow mesoporous carbon spheres with uniform mesoporous are more conducive to the dispersion of copper substances. The hollow mesoporous carbon spheres supported Cu catalyst showed better catalytic performance. When 2 nm Cu particles were added to the mesoporous carbon spheres, the DMC yield of the catalyst was 218.4 mg/(g·h), which was much higher than that of conventional carbon material supported Cu catalysts. Moreover, Cu species located in the shell and hollow can be self reduced to Cu2O active centers in the process of Cu2O activation due to the limitation of Cu2O localization environment. Thus, these catalyst shows high self reduction ability. In order to better obtain the catalytic performance of ethanol carbonylation catalyst, hollow carbon spheres encapsulated copper nanoparticles (Cu@HCS) catalysts was developed by Shi et al. [38] through adjusting the amount of resorcinol and formaldehyde. As shown in Fig. 4 , the size of Cu particle (2.2∼8.1 nm) is then controlled by changing the heating rate of the reduction process of catalysts. The carbon shell with mesoporous of the Cu@HCS is thin, which is conducive to the diffusion of related substances during reaction. Simultaneously, appropriate mesoporous on carbon shell and moderate Cu particle size can alleviate the leach of copper species. Thus, Cu@HCS catalyst shows higher stability during the oxidative carbonylation of methanol. And the activity and stability of the Cu@HCS catalyst are higher than those of commercial CuCl catalyst. The large surface area of mesoporous carbon materials is beneficial to the construction and dispersion of sufficient metal surface active sites. The ordered homogeneous and adjustable mesoporous channels or capsules (2∼50 nm) can provide a good nano confinement space, which can effectively control the size of active species and prevent the leach of catalytic active components in the preparation and reaction process. In order to to improve the catalytic performance of copper based catalysts, in addition to encapsulating the Cu species in the carbon material channel or cavity, the active Cu substance can also be firmly fixed on the surface of the catalytic support or embedded in the material interlayer. The carbon microsphere supported copper catalyst (Cu/CMS) was developed by Zhao et al. [39] using the strong anchoring ability of surface groups of the resin to the copper precursor. It is found that the sulfonic acid groups on the material surface can reduce the size of active Cu particle and promote the dispersion of Cu particle. When the size of Cu particle was about 5.5 nm, Cu/CMS-500 catalyst showed the DMC yield of 3770 mg/(g·h). As shown in Fig. 5 , the low-layer graphene was prepared by Shi et al. [40] using the lithium nitrate stripping. And the low-layer graphene supported copper catalysts with highly dispersed Cu nanoparticles was obtained by copper nitrate impregnation. The introduction of lithium nitrate can promote the removal of oxygen groups and reduces the burst temperature during heat treatment. This method can decompose Cu(NO3)2 into Cu particles with a size of about 4.2 nm. DFT results show that the presence of lithium in Cu/Li-graphene catalysts can produce high density charge transfer and high activity Cuδ+ species (0<δ<1) to reduce the energy barrier of the catalytic reaction process. The comparison of catalyst performance is shown in Table 1 . The above results indicated that the active copper species can be limited in the material pores through the confinement effect of porous carbon materials, which can effectively prevent the agglomeration of copper particles and improve the catalytic activity. Hollow bell shaped nano materials can be used as nano reactors due to the existence of cavities, which can provide the beneficial homogeneous environment for the coated nuclear components. In addition, the confinement of geometric space in the support material can effectively prevent the agglomeration and leach of active copper nuclear components, which has attracted great attention of researchers in recent years. These reported methods for stabilizing copper nanoparticles, such as inert support embedding, are mostly to form the limited system. The copper nanoparticles for chemical reaction is selected and regulated based on the limited effect, which provides a effective way to solve the stability problem. However, the construction process of confinement space in most porous carbon materials is complex and costly. And these preparation method has strong pertinence for coating noble metal nanoparticles. In order to meet the needs of many fields for nano materials with confinement effect, especially for non noble metal catalysts widely used in scientific research and industrial applications, it is of great significance to propose a simple and universal synthesis strategy. 2.2 Surface nitrogen group of carbon material for Cu nanoparticles control In recent years, N doped functional carbon materials have aroused great interest. Nitrogen heteroatoms incorporated into the carbon skeleton can enhance the local electron density of carbon materials and enhance the interaction between metals and the carbon materials support [44,45]. Nitrogen atoms in nitrogen doped carbon materials mainly exist in the form of pyridinic N, pyrrolic N and graphitic N. As shown in Fig. 6 , the nitrogen site connected to the two carbon atoms of the six-membered ring to form the sp2 hybrid structure is pyridine type nitrogen. In addition to providing an electron to the conjugated π bond system, this type of nitrogen also has additional lone electron pairs, which can be supplied to the transition metal to anchor the active metal on the material surface, thereby enhancing the electron transport characteristics. The nitrogen sites of the three carbon atoms connected to the graphitic basal plane are graphitic nitrogen. The nitrogen sites connected to the two carbon atoms of the five-membered ring are pyrrole-type nitrogens. These nitrogen atoms contain two p electrons conjugated to the conjugated π bond system. The local higher electron density may be beneficial to the growth of metal particles on nitrogen doped carbon materials [46,47]. Therefore, compared with traditional modification methods, the nitrogen doping process can significantly change the elemental composition of carbon materials, control even surface activity, and improve the physicochemical properties of carbon materials such as electronic properties, surface acidity and alkalinity [48,49]. As shown in Fig. 7 , N-doped carbon materials is mainly prepared by in-situ doping method and post-processing method [50,51]. The in-situ synthesis method refers to the introduction of nitrogen atoms while preparing carbon materials, and the nitrogen atoms are directly embedded into the framework of carbon materials during the carbonization process. Nitrogen-doped carbon materials prepared by in situ synthesis have high nitrogen content and the nitrogen atoms can be uniformly doped in carbon materials [52,53]. The post-treatment N-doped carbon materials can be obtained by heating existing carbon materials and nitrogen sources mixture in order to introduce the nitrogen atoms [54,55]. doped graphene (NG) can also immobilize metal nanoparticles. N-doped graphene with N content of 4.5-7.6 wt% was developed by Shi et al. [56] using hydrothermal method to treat graphene material soaked in ammonia. Compared with graphene supported copper catalyst, the catalytic performance of Cu/NG catalyst were significantly improved. As shown in Fig. 8 , the Cu particles size was reduced and the dispersion of Cu particles was improved due to the introduction of the doped N species. Noted that the dispersion and anchoring force of Cu particles on the NG can be improved due to the presence of the "activation zone" created by nitrogen species. Thus, the agglomeration and leach of Cu species during the reaction are alleviated. The introduction of nitrogen-containing groups into carbon materials support can promote the stability of Cu species nanoparticles in oxidative carbonylation reaction and improve the catalytic performance. N-doped carbon nanotubes (NCNTs) with different N contents were developed by Zhang et al. [57] through pre-oxidation and N-doped strategies. The surface oxygen groups of carbon nanotubes was improved through high temperature hydrothermal with the nitric acid. The increase of surface oxygen groups can improve the content of doped N species in the subsequent N doping process. With the increase of N content, the dispersion of Cu nanoparticles increased, which can improve the catalytic performance of the catalyst. The above studies indicated that the presence of doped N in carbon materials can improve the catalytic performance. Pyridine type nitrogen, pyrrole type nitrogen and graphite type nitrogen are the main nitrogen species formed in the process of nitrogen doping. However, the structure-activity relationship between catalytic performance and the type of N species in carbon materials needs to be further studied. Therefore, N-doped multiporous carbon nanomaterials were prepared by Zhang et al. [58] through direct pyrolysis of ZIF and polymethylphenylenediamine coated carbon black. The type and content of N species are controlled by selective etching of N-doped carbon materials using high temperature steam. The results show that N species have the synergistic catalytic effect on the methanol conversion. When the pyrrole nitrogen/pyridine nitrogen molar ratio is 2∼3, the obtained multi porous carbon supported copper has higher catalytic performance. The synergistic catalysis effect of layered porous structure and nitrogen species of N-doped carbon nanosheets-supported copper catalysts (Cu/NCNS) was also discovered by Pei et al. [59]. The results show that the layered porous structure of carbon nanosheets can produce new defects in the catalytic reaction process, which can promote the reconstruction of Cu species in the catalyst. These results can effectively inhibit the leaching and aggregation of Cu species. Moreover, the strong interaction between Cu0 and N can inhibit the oxidation of Cu0. Therefore, catalytic performance of the obtained catalyst did not decrease significantly after 10 catalytic cycles. It can be found that through the structural confinement of carbon materials and the doping of N species, the copper particles in the catalyst can be well controlled to improve the catalytic performance. In order to play the dual advantages of support confinement and N species doping, carbon supported N-doped graphene coated copper based catalysts (Cu@NG/C) was developed by Shi et al. [60] through direct co-pyrolysis. The optimal yield of DMC is 1881 mg/(g·h). N-doped graphene layer can not only promote the diffusion of reactants and product molecules, but also prevent the leaching and agglomeration of active Cu species. Simultaneously, the N species can improve the charge transfer ability and promote the adsorption of reaction gas on the copper sites. Therefore, the catalytic performance of Cu@NG/C is significantly improved. The catalyst composition and catalytic performance are summarized in Table 2 . The coating of graphene in the catalytic reaction can improve the stability and recoverability of the catalyst. When the metal nanoparticles are encapsulated in graphene, the agglomeration of Cu nanoparticles can be prevented due to the spatial confinement effect. Secondly, graphene coated metal nano materials have unique electron transfer ability and interfacial catalysis. The effective transmission of electrons from metal to shell can improve the catalytic activity of the materials [61,62]. Lei et al. [63] prepared in-situ nitrogen doped solid copper based catalysts with hierarchical pore structure through the copolymerization of tetravinyl phosphonium salt and divinylimidazolium salt. The obtained catalyst can be recovered by simple centrifugation, and 99% of the copper species remain in the catalyst after 10 times of reuse. Therefore, this work can provide a stable and recyclable solid catalyst for the preparation of DMC. In conclusion, the introduction of N species can provide more anchor sites for active metal and improve the dispersion of metal nanoparticles [64,65]. The improvement of catalytic characteristic of N-doped carbon materials supported Cu catalyst is mainly due to the synergistic effect between the confinement structure and the N specie, which can not only promote the dispersion of Cu nanoparticles, but also alleviate leach and oxidation of active Cu. Therefore, new technologies can be developed to combine confinement and doping technology to play the dual advantages of space confinement and heteroatom. In addition, the utilization of defects in N-doped carbon materials can be developed into a new way to improve the catalytic activity of carbon supported copper based catalysts. The nitrogen and oxygen groups on the carbon material surface can be regulated by nitrogen doping treatment and oxidation treatment. As shown in Fig. 11 , the oxygen-containing groups (OCGs) mainly include carbonyl, carboxyl, hydroxyl, quinones, anhydrides, lactones, etc. [66]. The oxygen-containing functional groups can enhance its hydrophilicity, which is conducive to the contact between the metal species and the support surface during the impregnation process. Meanwhile, oxygen-containing groups can provide nucleation sites for active metal and promote the uniform dispersion on the support surface [67,68]. Therefore, the effect of surface oxygen-containing groups on the control of metal dispersion and the catalytic performance has attracted great attention of researchers. The amount of the surface oxygen-containing groups can increase through the HNO3 and KMnO4 oxidation treatment. The most common oxidation treatment is to use HNO3 solution for oxidation. The amount of oxygen groups can be controlled by changing the treatment solubility time and temperature of the HNO3 solution [69,70]. Therefore, carbon materials not only have excellent structural properties, but also have many surface oxygen-containing groups. The interaction between Cu nanoparticles and carbon material can be enhanced by modifying the surface chemistry and improving the amount of the surface oxygen-containing groups, which can affect the valence distribution of Cu species in the decomposition or reduction stage. The influence of surface oxygen groups (C=O, COOH and OH) on the dispersion characteristic and catalytic performance of carbon aerogel (ACS) supported Cu particles was studied by Wang et al. [71]. As shown in the Fig. 12 , the catalytic activity has a linear relationship with the content of surface OCGs. With the increase of the surface oxygen-containing groups of activated carbon aerogel, the C=O oxygen-containing groups are enriched on the carbon aerogel surface, which contributed to the formation of small Cu nanoparticles. When the KOH/ACS mass ratio was 4, the space-time yield of DMC was 338.7 mg/(g·h). Noted that regulation of oxygen-containing groups is an effective strategy to adjust the catalytic performance of carbon-based supported copper catalysts. Zhao et al. [72] investigated the types and contents of surface oxygen-containing groups on the ordered mesoporous carbon by hydrogen peroxide oxidation. The results indicated that the oxygen content increased with the increase of H2O2 concentration. All forms of derivatized oxygen-containing groups increased to varying degrees after oxygen treatment. The increase of the number and type of oxygen-containing groups effectively improved the surface chemical properties and surface reaction kinetics of carbon materials. In order to better study the structure-activity relationship between the contents of oxygen-containing groups and valence distribution of Cu on the carbon material, the coconut shell carbon material was treated with HNO3 by Zhang et al. [73] to modify the surface properties of carbon material. The effect of HNO3 oxidation concentration on the type and contents of oxygen groups (such as lactones, carboxyl groups and phenol) was investigated. The results indicated that more oxygen-containing groups can provide more anchoring sites for copper species on the support surface. The stable surface oxygen groups are conducive to maintaining good dispersion of active copper species, while the unstable oxygen-containing groups are easily decomposed during the catalyst preparation and reaction process, resulting in the migration and growth of active copper species on the surface of the material [74,75]. These above two opposite effects jointly determine the dispersion degree of Cu species on the carbon support surface. The unstable surface oxygen groups of carbon materials can make copper species migrate and then lead to the agglomeration and leach. Therefore, it is necessary to remove the unstable oxygen-containing groups before the calcination process of carbon supported copper catalysts. Cheng et al. [76] investigated the influence of oxygen-containing functional groups on the dispersion and catalytic performance of acetylene hydrochlorination on Au-based catalysts. The results indicated that the surface oxygen groups, such as carboxyl and hydroxyl groups, can be increased by HNO3 oxidation treatment. The oxygen-containing groups can be selectively eliminated by heat treatment at different temperatures. The carboxyl group is eliminated first, followed by the hydroxyl group, and finally the carbonyl group during high-temperature treatment. The surface oxygen-containing groups, especially the hydroxyl groups, are beneficial to increase the hydrophilicity of the activated carbon support and promote the metal dispersion in the support. Based on the above research, the influence of surface oxygen groups (SOGs) in carbon materials on the formation of active copper species was also investigated by Zhang et al. [77]. The contents and type of surface oxygen groups in the activated carbon support were regulated by heat treatment at different temperatures. Noted that when the carbon materials were heat-treated at 600°C, the unstable carboxylic acid and acid anhydride groups were selectively removed, which prevent the migration and agglomeration of copper on the carbon material support during calcination. In addition, π sites are formed on the carbon substrate during high temperature heat treatment, which can promote the reduction of Cu2+ to Cu+ and Cu0, thereby improving the catalytic activity. The selective elimination of unstable SOGs in the carbon materials by heat treatment can help to further study the effect of oxygen groups on the Cu dispersion and catalytic performance of the catalyst. The catalytic performance of catalyst can be significantly improved by increasing the total amount of stable SOGs in carbon materials through processing with appropriate concentration of HNO3 or hydrogen peroxide. Compared with the carbon supported copper catalysts prepared by the mesoporous confinement method, it is more simple and economical to prepare high activity copper catalyst with heteroatom doped carbon material as support. 3 Effect of nitrogen and oxygen groups on the catalytic mechanism The mechanism of oxidative carbonylation of methanol to DMC over copper catalyst is shown in Fig. 14 [56]. The results show that methoxy group (Cu-OCH3) is first generated from methanol under the action of Cu+ and under aerobic conditions. The methoxycarbonyl species (MMC) are then generated as CO is inserted into the adsorbed Cu-OCH3 on Cu+. MMC reacts with a molecule of methanol to form DMC; Another way is that a molecule of methanol reacts with Cu-OCH3 to produce dimethoxy species, and CO is then inserted into dimethoxy species to produce DMC. The insertion of CO into Cu-OCH3 bond is the rate determining step of DMC formation. The mechanism of methanol conversion to dimethyl carbonate over Cu (II) catalyst were calculated by Kang wt al. [78]. The results indicated that the best way for DMC formation is CO insertion (CH3O)2. Simultaneously, the speed limiting step of DMC formation is also CO insertion (CH3O)2 process. The comparison of the most favorable DMC formation pathways in different valence Cu catalysts indicated that the valence of Cu has the important influence on the formation mechanism of DMC. The mechanism of oxidative carbonylation of methanol to DMC over CuO/activated carbon (CuO/AC) catalyst was studied by Ren et al. [79] using DFT method and cluster model. The adsorption of Cu0 on AC was studied and the most stable adsorption configurations (O, OH, CO, CH3O, CH3OH, DMC) on CuO/AC surface were given. The results show that CO insertion into dimethoxy and methoxy is the reaction rate limiting step of the two pathways respectively. Moreover, it is found that the activation energy of CO insertion into dimethoxy group is much higher than that of CO insertion into methoxy group. In order to deeply understand the influence of heteroatom doping on the synthesis mechanism of DMC, the energy barrier of CO insertion into CH3O on the N-doped graphene (Cu/PNG) surface and graphene oxide (Cu/rGO) was calculated by Shi et al. [56] through DFT. The initial, transitional and final structures of CO insertion reaction on Cu/PNG and Cu/rGO surfaces are shown in Fig. 15(a). Fig. 15(b) and (c) shows the optimized CO adsorption structure and transition state on Cu4/PNG and Cu4/rGO surfaces. Noted that the insertion reaction of CO needs to overcome the energy barrier of 89.6 KJ·mol−1 under the catalysis of Cu/rGO, while the energy barrier of Cu/PNG surface is only 67.5 KJ·mol−1. The calculation results indicated that the adsorption energy of CO on Cu/rGO surface is 97.1 KJ·mol−1, while that of CO on Cu/PNG surface is 43.7 KJ·mol−1, indicating that the introduction of N species in graphene can significantly promote the CO adsorption. Therefore, the above results indicated that the introduction of N species in Cu/PNG catalyst significantly improves the catalytic activity of methanol to DMC. The effect of different N type on the catalytic performance of graphene supported copper catalyst was systematically discussed by Han et al. [80] using density functional theory. The binding configurations of pyridine nitrogen (Cu/PNG), graphite nitrogen (Cu/GNG) and amino nitrogen (Cu/ANG) with copper atoms on graphene were studied. The binding energy was compared with that of copper supported original graphene (Cu/PG). The results show that the binding energies of Cu/PNG, Cu/GNG and Cu/ANG are 449.3, 655.0 and 615.4 kJ·mol respectively, which are higher than the binding energies of Cu/PG (229.4 kJ·mol), indicated that the presence of N species can promote the immobilization of Cu atoms on the catalyst. The above results showed that pyridine nitrogen and graphite nitrogen introduced into Cu/NG catalyst were beneficial to improve the formation rate of DMC, while the presence of amino nitrogen had the negative influence on the synthesis of dimethyl carbonate. The introduction of nitrogen species in graphene effectively provides anchor sites for copper atoms and chemical active sites for the formation of DMC. The electronic structure and catalytic activity of CO oxidation over N-doped graphene supported copper catalysts were systematically studied by Mehdi et al. [81]. The copper metal does not cluster in the N-doped graphene catalyst due to the large diffusion barrier, so the Cu atoms can be stably fixed on the N-doped graphene. It is found that there is a strong coupling between the Cu-3d state and the N-2p state, and the pyridine nitrogen around the Cu atom can promote the transfer of the bonding state of the Cu atom to the Fermi level. Therefore, N-doped graphene support can enhance CO adsorption compared with graphene supported Cu catalyst. The experimental results indicated that the surface oxygen-containing groups of carbon materials can promote the active Cu dispersion and enhance the interaction between Cu species and carbon support. Wang et al. [71] divided the surface oxygen groups into three types (C=O, COOH and OH) in order to further determine the effect of oxygen groups on the catalytic properties. The promotion effect of surface oxygen groups was determined from the micro level by constructing non-surface oxygen group (Fig. 16a), C=O (Fig. 16b), COOH (Fig. 16c) and OH (Fig. 16d) models. The results indicated that compared with the carbon material model without surface oxygen-containing groups, there was no significant difference in the binding energy of the catalyst when there were COOH and OH groups on the carbon material surface. However, the existence of C=O groups significantly improves the binding energy between Cu clusters and carbon material, thereby promoting the formation of small copper particles. 4 Conclusion and prospect In conclusion, the development of carbon material supported copper catalysts mainly starts from the following three aspects: (1) develop highly active structural confinement carbon material catalyst systems, mainly copper based carbon nanotubes, carbon nanospheres and mesoporous carbon; (2) nitrogen or oxygen-containing groups (hydroxyl and carbonyl) are introduced into the surface of carbon materials through heteroatom doping to strengthen the fixation of copper particles on the support and prevent the leach and agglomeration of copper species; (3) the carbon material is modified to change its surface element composition on the basis of using the structural confinement carbon material in order to give the double advantages of structural confinement and surface heteroatom modification. The copper species were stabilized by the anchoring effect of surface functional groups and the space confinement effect of the carbon material. The development of the above carbon material supports has improved the catalytic performance of the copper based carbon material catalyst for methanol oxidative carbonylation to a certain extent. However, after a long time of catalytic reaction, the particles of copper active species in carbon material catalysts become larger and oxidized. Thus, the deactivation rate of catalyst is still high. Moreover, compared with the industrial catalyst that needs long-term operation, the carbon material catalyst currently developed has a shorter service life due to the oxidation and leach of copper species, which is the key issue whether the oxidative carbonylation of methanol to DMC can be industrialized. Therefore, it is still a challenge to develop carbon supported copper catalysts with adjustable valence distribution and without active copper species loss after long-term reaction. Meanwhile, the control formation and cyclic regeneration mechanism of heteroatom functional groups in carbon supported copper catalysts is not clear. The influence mechanism of the introduced heteroatom groups on the valence, dispersion and catalytic properties of active copper needs to be further explored. Moreover, the understand of synergistic effect of heteroatom species and active copper on the activation mode of reactive substance is not wide and deep enough. The activation and conversion of intermediate products can not be accurately controlled, and further research is urgently needed. Thus, this work can provide effective guidance for solving the above problems faced by carbon material supported copper catalysts, (Figs. 9, 10 and 13, Table 3 ). coredata.dc:description: The preparation of high value-added chemicals such as dimethyl carbonate (DMC) by oxidative carbonylation of methanol with carbon materials supported copper (Cu) catalysts is an important development direction of clean and efficient utilization of coal. However, Cu nanoparticles of carbon supported copper catalysts are prone to agglomeration and oxidation in the catalytic process of oxidative carbonylation of methanol. And the development of catalysts is the key issue whether the oxidative carbonylation of methanol to DMC can be industrialized. The Cu species can be controlled by heteroatoms doping and structural confinement of carbon materials support in order to increase the catalytic activity of carbon supported copper catalysts. The recent approaches in the control of Cu nanoparticles in carbon supported copper catalysts is reviewed in this paper, the principles and characteristics of various regulation methods are introduced in detail. The problems existing in the research and the direction of improvement are then analyzed and discussed. The future development of carbon materials supported copper catalysts for the preparation of DMC was prospected. Thus, this work can provide effective guidance for the preparation of high efficiency carbon supported Cu catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Copper nanoparticles control of carbon supported copper catalysts for dimethyl carbonate synthesis: A short review
